title: Bohr - rank electron dB wavelength for systems XYZ

content.question:
In the standing-wave model for an electron in a circular orbit around a nucleus, the orbit’s circumference must be an integer multiple of the electron’s de Broglie wavelength. In each of three different systems <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math>, <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Z</mtext></math>, a single electron is modeled as being in a circular orbit around a nucleus. The three systems are described as follows.
• In system <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math>, an electron orbits a hydrogen nucleus <math alttext="H with mass number 1 and atomic number 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><mmultiscripts><mtext>H</mtext><mprescripts></mprescripts><mn>1</mn><mn>1</mn></mmultiscripts><mo>)</mo></math> in the ground state (smallest orbit possible).
• In system <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math>, an electron orbits a helium nucleus <math alttext="H e with mass number 4 and atomic number 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>(</mo><mmultiscripts><mtext>He</mtext><mprescripts></mprescripts><mn>2</mn><mn>4</mn></mmultiscripts><mo>)</mo></mstyle></math> in the ground state (smallest orbit possible).
• In system <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Z</mtext></math>, an electron orbits a hydrogen nucleus <math alttext="H with mass number 1 and atomic number 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><mmultiscripts><mtext>H</mtext><mprescripts></mprescripts><mn>1</mn><mn>1</mn></mmultiscripts><mo>)</mo></math> in the second-smallest orbit possible.
Which of the following correctly ranks the number <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi></math> of de Broglie wavelengths that fit around the circumferences of the electrons’ orbits in systems <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math>, <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Z</mtext></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="n sub Y is greater than, n sub Z, which is greater than n sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="n sub Y equals, n sub Z, which is greater than n sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="n sub Z is greater than, n sub Y, which is greater than n sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="n sub Z is greater than, n sub X, which equals n sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="n sub Z is greater than, n sub X, which equals n sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>
